“Journalists in the Democratic Republic of the Congo are too often subjected to violent harassment and detention,” @angelaquintal said. 

The officers who arrested Mulamba wore hoods, forced their way into the home, broke doors and windows, and fired shots into the air.

#Ethiopia: On April 21 a court in Oromia approved police request to continue the detention of Oromia News Network journalists Dessu Dulla and Bikila Amenu, amid seemingly indefinite investigations against them. CPJ calls for their unconditional release. https://t.co/NNvvc0U3Vw

@pressfreedom @hrcsomaliland CPJ calls on #Somaliland authorities unconditionally release Mohamed Ilig, Abdijabar Hussein, and Abdirahman Khalif, and to stop detaining journalists in retaliation for their work.

@pressfreedom @hrcsomaliland The journalists were part of a group arrested on April 13 in connection to coverage of a prison riot. One of the journalists, MM TV’s Mohamed Ilig, is suffering from severe health issues, according to @hrcsomaliland. Read CPJ’s research on the case:

https://t.co/YStaBs3Koa

@pressfreedom However, CPJ is very concerned by @hrcsomaliland's reports that 3 other journalists who remain in detention — Mohamed Ilig, Abdijabar Hussein, and Abdirahman Khalif– are facing allegations of disseminating false news and anti-national propaganda.

https://t.co/9xjgsjsAA6

#Somaliland: CPJ welcomes the April 20 release of journalist Abdisalan Ahmed Awad, and calls on authorities to discontinue any pending case against him and to desist from harassing him. Read @pressfreedom’s reporting on his case:

https://t.co/VVO5F3Nisp

“Thiam’s beating by authorities sends a chilling message that the press is not safe in #Senegal. A thorough investigation should be carried out and those responsible should be held accountable,” @muthokimumo said. https://t.co/Ho7kyeGcNn
“Senegalese authorities should drop their prosecution of journalist Pape Malick Thiam and allow him to work free of harassment and intimidation,” said @muthokimumo.

Thiam is scheduled to appear before a #Dakar court on April 20 for alleged “contempt of an agent in the exercise of his duties.” 

If convicted, Thiam could face up to three months in prison and a maximum fine of 50,000 West African francs ($83). https://t.co/tXmlEYsetW

@pressfreedom #Senegal: Gendarme officers arrested Thiam, a @7tvOfficielle reporter, while he was on assignment at a Dakar court on April 14.

7TV Executive Director Maimouna Ndour Faye said officers “severely” beat Thiam. He had swelling in his face and bloody clothes. https://t.co/Ho7kyeGcNn

Authorities in #Senegal should drop their prosecution of journalist Pape Malick Thiam, ensure he can work free of intimidation, and hold those responsible for beating him to account - @pressfreedom https://t.co/Ho7kyeGcNn

#Somaliland authorities must also release online journalist Abdisalan Ahmed Awad (also known as Germany) who has been detained in Hargeisa since April 3 in connection to his Facebook posts. 

Read @pressfreedom’s reporting on his case: 

https://t.co/VVO5F3Nisp

On April 13, #Somaliland security personnel carried out a mass arrest of journalists covering a prison riot. At that time, CPJ was unaware of the arrest of Gobonimo TV’s Abdirahman Khalif, still detained, and SomNews journalist Hussein Abees, now released.
https://t.co/YStaBs3Koa

#Somaliland: CPJ welcomes the unconditional release of a group of journalists detained in Hargeisa since April 13 and calls on authorities to unconditionally free 3 others – Mohamed Ilig, Abdijabar Hussein, and Abdirahman Khalif – who remain behind bars.

https://t.co/c0l1cpBTwt

@pressfreedom The remaining 13 detained journalists were brought to court today and have been remanded in custody for a further 5 days. #Somaliland authorities must stop this intolerance towards independent media & free them immediately. “A free flow of information and unfettered access is key to holding credible elections and any attempt to interfere with or stop journalists from doing their jobs must be condemned and action taken to ensure it does not happen again,” @angelaquintal said. https://t.co/WqJvwYIm5z

“We urge the opposition Citizens Coalition for Change and other political parties participating in this weekend’s election and beyond to champion press freedom and ensure that members of the press are not harmed,” said @angelaquintal.

Zimbabwean political parties participating in the March 26 by-election must ensure journalists can cover the events freely and prevent their supporters and officials from harassing or assaulting the press - @pressfreedom https://t.co/WqJvwYIm5z

There are at least 4 journalists currently jailed in connection with their work in #Cameroon; 2 have been released since December 1, 2021, when CPJ conducted its last census of journalists behind bars for their work around the world. https://t.co/7fyJPB9Gws

“Cameroonian authorities should drop their prosecution of journalist Malcolm Barnabé Paho and reform the country’s laws to ensure journalism is not criminalized,” said @angelaquintal. “Cameroon should focus on ensuring that there are no journalists in jail, not look to add more.”

#Cameroon journalist Malcolm Barnabé Paho detained for 2 days, prosecuted for defamation

Cameroonian authorities should drop the prosecution of journalist Malcom Bernabé Paho and decriminalize journalism in the country - @pressfreedom https://t.co/Vi9lzJ3iNw

The telecom regulator also agreed to inform the #Zambia-n public of the reason for any interruption in access to the internet within thirty-six hours of any such event in the county, according to @CofZambia's statement.

On August 13 last year, @CofZambia filed an application challenging the shutdown & obtained a court order to have the internet restored.  This week it entered into a consent judgement in which the regulator agreed not to act outside its legal authority to restrict the internet.

.@CofZambia says that going forward the agreement  "will ensure accountability for any internet shutdown that may occur in the future". It follows last year's internet shutdown on election day (Aug 12) that affected all social media platforms.  #KeetItOn
https://t.co/0AxY95Mqg9

.@pressfreedom welcomes the recent agreement between @CofZambia & #Zambia's telecoms regulator that was made an order of court & has been heralded as an "enormous victory for internet freedom and freedom of expression in the country" #KeepItOn https://t.co/P9z4mfR8Xx

Gwanda covered mysterious killings in his community.
 
#WhereIsAzory?

Arrested on March 10 alongside 7 colleagues, Bikobere and Tumuhimbise are charged with cyberstalking the president.

Press freedom has been on the decline in #Ethiopia for the past two years, a sharply disappointing state of affairs given the hope and optimism of early 2018 when Abiy Ahmed Ali became prime minister.

Since November 2020,  @pressfreedom has documented the arrests of at least 10 journalists &  media workers who were held for periods ranging from a few days to 2 months& whose detentions were connected to their coverage of the Tigray conflict or were accused of links to the TPLF.

.@pressfreedom again urges #Ethiopia-n authorities and other political actors to ensure that both local and international media have the access they need to report the elections and to guarantee that journalists will not face retaliation for critical coverage.
Today’s expulsion is yet another example of the lengths the #Ethiopian government will go to control reporting,  particularly on the conflict in Tigray and ahead of  next month’s election.

.@pressfreedom urges the government of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed to immediately rescind the expulsion and allow Simon Marks to return to #Ethiopia where he can continue his journalism freely & without further reprisal.

Em 2012, o CPJ documentou como soldados da Guiné – Bissau prenderam o jornalista António Aly Silva e o ameaçaram de morte, levando-o a fugir do país.

It is not too late for the #Ethiopia-n government to reverse course & to ensure it lives up to the initial hope of meaningful press freedom reform.  Key to this is for authorities to free all detained journalists & to stop weaponizing the judicial system to intimidate the press.

A mere two years later, #Ethiopia is back on the list of worst jailers of journalists in sub-Saharan Africa, with 7 journos behind bars, according to @pressfreedom’s latest census of imprisoned journalists  on December 1 — third after #Eritrea (16) & #Cameroon (8)

In the first year of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed’s administration in 2018, #Ethiopia did not have a single journalist in jail for their work for the first time since 2004, according to @pressfreedom’s census of imprisoned journalists that year. There was genuine hope for reform.

This year @pressfreedom documented a worrying pattern of holding journalists for weeks without formal charge in Ethiopia. Today another journalist Dawit Kebede, who was arrested on November 30, is due to appear in court. He has been detained without charge for almost a month.

https://t.co/7KTdOo0Oa2

@pressfreedom Last year, #Tanzania’s foreign minister claimed #AzoryGwanda was dead, but later retracted his comments. 

https://t.co/pOQufJGFmS

@pressfreedom Despite a missing persons report and numerous appeals by Gwanda’s family, colleagues, and rights groups, authorities in #Tanzania have failed to carry out a credible investigation into his disappearance.

@pressfreedom Anna Pinoni, #AzoryGwanda’s, wife was one of the last people to see him on November 21, 2017, when he came to their farm in a white Landcruiser and in the company of unknown men, saying he was leaving on an urgent trip. She hasn’t seen him since. 

https://t.co/63TrsIpIue

@pressfreedom In the months before he went missing, #AzoryGwanda chronicled a spate of murders that had thrown his community into turmoil. He reported about families forced to witness the killings of their loved ones. He covered the security response to the killings. 

https://t.co/NYkknPlTTC

#Tanzania-n freelancer #AzoryGwanda went missing THREE years ago TODAY. 

Join @pressfreedom in demanding answers on the whereabouts of this journalist who is #MissingNotForgotten. #WhereIsAzory? #MrudisheniAzory

Both cases stemmed from 2016, when authorities raided @JamiiForums and arrested Melo: https://t.co/bz3O7yNlVp

The judgment was unclear on the consequences of breaching the terms of @macdemelo’s discharge. #Tanzania’s penal code says a judge may issue an arrest warrant and new sentence if an individual on conditional discharge is convicted of a separate offense. https://t.co/iQG1JrEVe1

“This ruling entrenches the dangerous message that the Tanzanian media cannot expect to protect sources. Tanzanian authorities should guarantee that Melo will not face prosecution for his work and reassure the media that they will not be forced to reveal sources.” @angelaquintal

“While we welcome the decision to acquit Maxence Melo on one of the trumped-up charges against him, his conviction on an obstruction charge is deeply disappointing and his conditional release leaves the door open for further judicial harassment,” said @angelaquintal.
The court did not fine @macdemelo or sentence him to prison, and released him on the condition that he not commit any criminal offenses for one year.

On November 17, the court acquitted @macdemelo on charges of operating a website that was not registered in #Tanzania, but convicted him of obstructing police investigations by failing to disclose the personal data of whistleblowers who used his platform. https://t.co/iQG1JrEVe1
